BOTANICAL AND MINERAL SUBSTANCES USED IN THE PRESCRIPTIONS 471 kikkirânu (šimŠE.LI): kikkirânu-substance; un-identified aromatic plant; according to Uruanna III 459 a designation for burāšu-juniper seed. kirbān eqli (úLAG-A.ŠÀ(.GA)/GÁN/GÁ): ‘field-clod’-plant (translation of the Sumerian and Akka-dian name); unidentified medicinal plant. kiššēnu (GÚ.NÍG.ḪAR.RA): a legume. kitû (úGADA): flax. kukuru (šimGÚR.GÚR): kukuru-plant; an aromatic plant, often used for fumigation, which according to incantations originates in the ‘mountains’. kunāšu (ZÍZ.ÀM): emmer. kupru (ESIR.UD.DU): tar pitch. kurkānû, kulkanû (ú/šimKUR.GI.RIN.NA): kurkānû-plant; unidentified medicinal plant, probably an aromatic; Thompson, DAB, 157–61, suggested an identification with turmeric, but this remains un-certain. úkuṣimtu: kuṣimtu-plant; unidentified medicinal plant, attested only in text 10.3: 16′; perhaps a variant of kuṣīmu or kurṣimtu. kutpû (na4AN.ZAḪ.GE6): black frit. úla(l)la(n)gu: lal(l)a(n)gu-pea; an unidentified legume. laptu (úLU.ÚBsar): turnip. lapat armanni: ‘apricot-turnip’; unidentified medicinal plant, possibly a kind of turnip. lapat eqli: ‘field’-turnip; a turnip variety. (giš)libāru: libāru-fruit; a fruit tree or shrub. lišān kalbi (úEME-UR.GI7): ‘dog’s tongue’ (translation of the Sumerian and Akkadian name); medicinal plant, possibly to be identified with Cynoglossum (hound’s tongue). úMA.GIL: MA.GIL-plant; unidentified medicinal plant; Akkadian reading uncertain. maštakal, ammaštakal (úIN.NU.UŠ, úIN6.ÚŠ): maštakal-soapwort; medicinal plant, the purifying drug par excellence, probably to be identified with a soapwort. See Thompson, DAB, 39–43; cf. also Maul, BaF 18, 65. merrutu: probably a medicinal plant; see text 1.1, 1.: 28′ and text 2.2, 1.: 130′′′′. úmirānu: mirānu-plant; unidentified medicinal plant. munziqu (GEŠTIN.ḪÁD.A): raisin. murdudû (ú/gišMUR.DÙ.DÙ): murdudû-plant; un-identified medicinal plant. šim?murrān: only in text 10.3: 45′; certainly identical with murrānu, an oil-producing tree or shrub. murru (šimSES): myrrh. na4mūṣu: mūṣu-stone; for mūṣu “bilharzia” and (na4)mūṣu “calculus discharged from the urinary passage”, see Kinnier Wilson, JNES 27 (1968) 245–46, Herrero, RA 69 (1975) 49–50 and Schuster-Brandis, Steine, 431–32. muššaru (na4NÍR.MUŠ.GÍR): muššaru-stone; a stone with red and white stripes (banded agate); see Schuster-Brandis, Steine, 433. nab/mruqqu: nab/mruqqu-plant; unidentified me-dicinal plant. nikiptu (ŠIM.dMAŠ/dNIN.URTA): nikiptu-plant; un-identified aromatic, gum-yielding plant, possibly a Euphorbia shrub (spurge). nīnû (Ú.KUR.RA): nīnû-plant; unidentified plant, used in medical contexts and as a spice. Based on Aramaic and Syriac cognates Thompson, DAB, 67–69, suggested an identification as Ammi (bishop’s weed); Kinnier Wilson, JNES 64 (2005) 50–51 argues for an identification with mint. nuḫurtu (úNU.LUḪ.ḪA): nuḫurtu-plant; unidenti-fied medicinal plant, often used against witchcraft; according to Thompson, DAB, 353–59, to be identi-fied with asafoetida. úNU.LUḪ: NU.LUḪ-plant; unidentified medicinal plant; possibly an alternative spelling of tīyatu (úKU.NU.LUḪ.ḪA), distinguished from, but associ-ated with nuḫurtu (úNU.LUḪ.ḪA); cf. text 7.10.1, 1.: 95′′ and the commentary on text 1.1, 1.: 22′. nurmû (gišNU.ÚR.MA): pomegranate. únuṣābu: nuṣābu-plant; unidentified medicinal plant. pappardilû (na4(NÍR.)BABBAR.DIL): (nir)pappar-dilû-stone; a black stone with one white stripe; see Schuster-Brandis, Steine, 403–404. papparḫû (úBABBAR.ḪIsar): a garden plant; a pos-sible Syriac cognate suggests an identification with purslane. parzillu (AN.BAR), na4AN.BAR: iron; when de-termined by NA4 (‘iron stone’) it designates an iron bead (or perhaps a stone bead whose appearance is similar to iron). pillû (ú/gišNAM.TAR/TAL): pillû-plant; medicinal plant, the identification with mandrake (so Thomp-son, DAB, 217–19) remains uncertain.

REGISTERS 472 pindû (na4ŠE.TIR): pindû-stone; a mottled type of limestone; see Schuster-Brandis, Steine, 443–44. piriggunû (na4PÌRIG.GÙN.A): piriggunû-stone; see Steinkeller, ZA 77 (1987) 92–95, Civil, Ebla 1975–1985, 151. pû (IM.BUBBU): chaff. úpuquttu: puquttu-thorn. qadūt šikani (IM.GÚ.EN.NA): river sediment. qan appāri: ‘marsh’-reed; a variety of reed. qan-šalāli (GI.ŠUL.ḪI): šalālu-reed; a variety of reed. qanû ṭābu (GI DU10.GA): ‘sweet’ reed; a variety of reed. qutru (úKI.dIŠKUR): qutru-plant; unidentified me-dicinal plant. ruʾtītu (ÚḪ.dÍD): ruʾtītu-sulphur, explained by a commentary as kibrītu aruqtu “green (or: yellow) sulphur”. úSAG: SAG-plant; unidentified medicinal plant; equated with la-a-ar-tu in Ḫḫ XVII (MSL 10, 108: 25, CAD L 103a), therefore lardu-grass? saḫḫû: saḫḫû-mineral; an unidentifed mineral or stone; see Schuster-Brandis, Steine, 441. saḫlû (ZÀ.ḪI.LIsar): cress (?); a garden-plant, iden-tification not entirely certain. For a full discussion, see Stol, JEOL 28 (1983–84) 24–32; but cf. the ob-jections raised by Köcher, AUWE 10, 212. samīdu (úKUR.ZI): samīdu-plant; unidentified vegetable, spice and medicinal plant. sāmtu (na4GUG): literally “red (stone)”, here con-ventionally translated as “carnelian”, even though the use of the name is not restricted to carnelian. úsibbirru, simbirru: sibbirru-plant; an unidenti-fied medicinal plant and spice, associated with šib-burratu in pharmaceutical texts. giš/úsīḫu, šīḫu: sīhu-plant; an aromatic plant (shrub or tree?) and its resin; the identification with wormwood is based on etymology alone. sikillu (úSIKIL): sikillu-plant, literally “the pure (herb)”; unidentified medicinal plant. Uruanna I 6 associates sikillu with maštakal-soapwort, ibid. I 19 sikillu is designated as “soapwort of the moun-tain(s)” (maltakal šadî). Šammu šikinšu notes that its leaves are similar to those of the ḫašḫūr api (STT 93 obv. 46′–47′). siparru (ZABAR): bronze; bronze bead. suādu (šimMAN.DU, in text 2.1, 1.: 138′′′′ šimIM.DU): suādu-plant; an aromatic plant; probably to be identified with chufa (yellow nutsedge). suḫuššu (gišGIŠIMMAR.TUR): palm shoots. suluppū (ZÚ.LUM.MA): date(s). supālu (gišZA.BA.LAM; úNIGINsar in text 2.5, 1.: 12′): supālu-juniper; probably a variety of juniper. úṣaṣumtu (ṣaṣuttu): ṣaṣumtu-plant; unidentified medicinal plant, according to BAM 1 obv. II 3 // one of the drugs effective against ašû-disease, but mentioned side by side with šammi ašî in text 7.10.1, 1.: 65′′, 73′′. ṣumlalû (šimGAM.MA): ṣumlalû-spice; an un-identified spice and aromatic plant. šadânu (na4KA.GI.NA): šadânu-stone (probably haematite); regarded as a stone of truth (cf. the Sumerian name), used especially for gaining favour; cf. Schuster-Brandis, Steine, 424–25. šadânu ṣābitu (na4KA.GI.NA DAB.BA): magnetite; regarded as a stone of truth (cf. the Sumerian name), used especially for gaining favour; cf. Schuster-Brandis, Steine, 424–25. šakirû (úŠAKIRA): šakirû-plant; unidentified plant, mostly attested in medical contexts. A possible Syriac cognate suggests an identification with henbane. šammi(Ú) ašî: ašû-disease-plant; unidentified medicinal plant. šammi balāṭi (Ú.NAM.TI.LA): ‘plant-of-life’ (translation of the Sumerian and Akkadian name); unidentified medicinal plant. šammi Lamašti: Lamaštu-plant (translation of the Akkadian name); unidentified medicinal plant. šammu matqu: ‘sweet herb’ (translation of the Akkadian name); unidentified medicinal plant associated with ariḫu. šammu peṣû (Ú.BABBAR): ‘white plant’ (trans-lation of the Sumerian and Akkadian name); ac-cording to Uruanna I 226–27 a designation of the resin of the Euphrates poplar. šarmadu (úGUR5.UŠ): šarmadu-plant; unidenti-fied medicinal plant. šeʾu (ŠE): barley. šibburratu (úLUḪ.MAR.TU): šibburratu-plant; unidentified medicinal plant; a possible Syriac cog-nate suggests an identification with rue. úšimru: šimru-fennel; cf. urânu and Ú.KU6.

BOTANICAL AND MINERAL SUBSTANCES USED IN THE PRESCRIPTIONS 473 šubû (na4ŠUBA): šubû-stone; material used for beads and seals; according to Schuster-Brandis, Steine, 446, rather a shell or a cowry snail than a mineral. šūmu (SUMsar): garlic. šumuttu (úSUMUN.DAR): beetroot (?); a field and garden plant well known for its red colour and asso-ciated with blood; its identification with beetroot is not entirely certain. šunû (gišŠE.NÁ.A): chaste tree (?). šupuḫru (gišEREN.BAD): šupuḫru-cedar; a variety of cedar. šurdunû (úSI.SÁ): šurdunû-plant; unidentified medicinal plant, possibly rocket. šurmēnu (gišŠUR.MÌN): cypress. šuršummū šikari: beer dregs. giššūšu (gišŠE.DÙ): licorice (tree). útarmuš: lupine; identification based on Aramaic and Arabic cognates, see Thompson, DAB, 125–26. CAD T 239a points out that “the plant’s description as šammi nipši points to a plant propagated by airborne seeds”; but nipšu may well refer to the characteristic smell of the plant. terinnatu (gišŠE.Ù.SUḪ5): conifer cone. tittu (gišPÈŠ): fig(-tree). tīyatu (úKU.NU.LUḪ(.ḪA)): tīyatu-plant; un-identified plant, used in medical contexts and as a spice, regularly combined and associated with nuḫurtu; cf. the commentary on text 1.1, 1.: 22′. útiskur: tiskur-plant; unidentified medicinal plant. útullal: tullal-plant; unidentified medicinal plant. The name was interpreted as Akkadian tullal “you purify”; it is associated with maštakal-soapwort in Uruanna I 4–5. turminû (na4DUR.MI.NA): turminû-breccia. turminabandû (na4DUR.MI.NA.BÀN.DA): turmina-bandû-breccia; a dark stone, see Schuster-Brandis, Steine, 406. turû (SUM.ŠIR.DILI): turû-garlic, probably single-clove garlic. ṭābtu (MUN): salt. ṭābat amanni (MUN a-ma-nim): amannu-salt; a red variety of salt, see Streck, RlA 11 (2008) 593. ṭābat emesalli (MUN eme-sal-lim): emesallu-salt; a variety of salt, literally “salt of the fine tongue”. ṭābat kupad (MUN kù/ku-pad): kupad-salt; a variety of salt; cf. Köcher, AUWE 10, 212. For the syllabic spelling ṭà-⌈ab⌉-ti ku-pa-ad, see text 2.1, 1.: 1 (OB). tērītu: silt. Ú.KU6: Ú.KU6-fennel (a literal translation of the logogram is perhaps ‘fish’-plant); a variety of fen-nel, Akkadian reading and exact relationship to urânu and šimru unknown. ÚḪ A.AB.BA: ‘spittle-of-the-sea’ (translation of the Sumerian name); unidentified mineral; probably to be read illāt tâmti in Akkadian, see commentary on text 1.1, 1.: 123′′′′′′. uḫultu: soda ash; designates salt-plants and their alkaline ashes. uḫūlu (NAGA): potash; designates salt-plants and their alkaline ashes. (uḫūlu) qarnānû (NAGA SI): ‘horned’ salt-plant; probably a variety of Salicornia. uqnû (na4ZA.GÌN): here conventionally translated as “lapis lazuli”, even though the name is not restricted to lapis lazuli proper, but can refer to other blue stones as well. urânu, urânnu (úTÁL.TÁL): urânu-fennel?; a vegetable and medicinal plant, probably a variety of fennel. úurnû: urnû-plant; unidentified medicinal plant; the association with (a)naniḫu may suggest an iden-tification with Ammi (probably not mint, as suggested by Thompson, DAB, 77–79). na4yānibu: yānibu-‘stone’; a shell or cowry snail; see Schuster-Brandis, Steine, 421. zalāqu (na4ZÁLAG): zalāqu-stone; a light-coloured stone. na4zibītu: zibītu-stone; an unidentified mineral, perhaps a shell; see Schuster-Brandis, Steine, 456.
